docs.lead_paragraph: In Boston, scientists measuring the city’s greenhouse gas emissions have found what they call a “weekend effect,” a clear drop-off in the amount of carbon dioxide entering the city’s atmosphere on Saturdays and Sundays. In Fresno, researchers have discovered that backyard water use increases with wealth, as does backyard biodiversity. And in Los Angeles, ecologists studying the city’s “ecohydrology” have calculated that planting a million new trees, an idea with fairly universal appeal, would have the drawback of increasing water consumption by 5 percent.
docs.abstract: Twenty-one federally financed projects are under way to understand urban water use, greenhouse gas emissions, storm water runoff and biodiversity.

headline.main: As Ecosystems, Cities Yield Some Surprises

docs.snippet: Twenty-one federally financed projects are under way to understand urban water use, greenhouse gas emissions, storm water runoff and biodiversity....

docs.lead_paragraph: While the rest of East Asia erupts in celebrations to honor the Buddha's birthday, residents of the small dumbbell-shaped island of Cheung Chau - less than an hour's ferry ride from Hong Kong's Central district - literally march to their own tune. The annual five-day Cheung Chau Bun Festival culminates this year on May 21. Nearly 40,000 people are expected to flood this fishing haven, then to make merry and enjoy the holiday's namesake steamed buns, filled with sweet paste and stamped with the crimson Chinese character for "peace."
docs.abstract: The annual five-day Cheung Chau Bun Festival culminates this year on May 21 on the small island of Cheung Chau near Hong Kong.

headline.main: Hong Kong's Celebration of the Bun

docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS | Popular myth suggests that through the medieval era personal hygiene was far from a priority. But an exhibition at the Musée du Moyen Âge (6, place Paul-Painlevé; 33-1-53-73-78-00; www.musee-moyenage.fr) testifies to the era's surprisingly involved beauty and grooming culture. From ancient hair dying techniques to fourth-century ear picks (the predecessor of the Q-tip), "The Bath and the Mirror: Body Care and Cosmetics from Antiquity to the Middle Ages" showcases the tools of vain medieval maidens.
